title: Nurses transforming systems of care: The bicentennial of Florence Nightingale's legacy
abstract: This paper explores the impact of Florence Nightingale's legacy on the contemporary healthcare system. A review of primary sources from the 19th century shows us how Nurses have evolved their roles to become a decisive part of patient care during hospitalizations and beyond, transforming systems of care towards improved outcomes for patients.

title: Identification of one B-cell epitope from NS1 protein of duck Tembusu virus with monoclonal antibodies
abstract: This study presents the identification of a B-cell epitope from the NS1 protein of Duck Tembusu virus, using monoclonal antibodies. Analysis of various antigenic regions in this pathogen found one conformational contiguous epitope with high binding affinity for Mouse Monoclonal Antibody 2G9 (MAb2G9). Further examination revealed MAb peptide interaction through hydrogen bonding and conformational entropy changes before the determination of its exact amino acid sequence. In conclusion, an isolated epitope was responsible for antigen recognition by monoclonal antibodies which can be used to design novel vaccine candidates against duck Tembusu virus infection in poultry flocks.

title: Volatile fingerprinting of human respiratory viruses from cell culture
abstract: This research paper presents the volatile fingerprinting technique utilized to identify human respiratory viruses from cell culture. An aerosol sampling system was used to generate air samples of up to 0.25 liters, collected during viral replication in various types of cell cultures – Vero E6, LLC-PK1, Sp2/0 and MDCK II cell lines. Using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS), a wide range of known volatile compounds were detected using retention time indices through library matching with Wakitta’s standard reference collection for volatiles and Pherobank for semiochemicals used to study biodiversity distribution patterns. The ability to detect specific chemicals present within certain viruses can be attributed largely in part to their lifestyle as obligate intracellular parasites, causing them to interact more closely with host cells than extracellular viruses do. Volatile fingerprinting provides an additional tool that could be useful when attemptingto identify common human respiratory pathogens accurately and rapidly which would form the basis of early diagnosis or surveillance purposes at point of care facilities or other medical institutions worldwide

title: Challenges in modelling complexity of fungal entomopathogens in semi-natural populations of insects
abstract: This study aims to explore the complexity of fungal entomopathogens in semi-natural populations of insects. While advances have been made in recent years, significant challenges remain for developing accurate models that express this intricate web of interactions between fungi and their insect hosts. This research defines the scope for emerging technologies and improved theoretical approaches to overcome current limitations and provide more comprehensive predictive models. By providing an overview of both current studies as well as future possibilities, this paper may guide the development of informatics applied to myconto-entomological studies, particularly those in the field of semi-natural population monitoring and disease control.

title: Identification of 2-(4-(Phenylsulfonyl)piperazine-1-yl)pyrimidine Analogues as Novel Inhibitors of Chikungunya Virus
abstract: This study aimed to identify 2-(4-(Phenylsulfonyl)piperazine-1-yl)pyrimidine analogues as novel small molecule inhibitors of Chikungunya Virus (CHIKV). Following extensive analysis and evaluations, the evaluation and comparison of potency, selectivity and cytotoxicity of a set of newly synthesized compounds revealed that they could be leveraged as potent inhibitors against CHIKV replication. Consequently, we report the discovery and identification of 2-(4-(Phenylsulfonylists piperazine-1=yl)pyrimidine analogues as worthy candidates for further research on CHIKV antiviral treatments.

title: Studies of an outbreak of acute hepatitis A: II. Antibody changes to cytomegalovirus and herpesvirus
abstract: This study seeks to identify the potential link between acute hepatitis A and antibody changes for cytomegalovirus and herpesvirus. Using a sample of 350 patients, antibody levels were measured pre-and post-infection in order to understand clinical correlations. Results will help inform future clinical decisions regarding the diagnosis and management of co-occurring viral infections.

title: Archaeal DnaG contains a conserved N-terminal RNA-binding domain and enables tailing of rRNA by the exosome
abstract: This study provides evidence for the presence of a conserved N-terminal RNA-binding domain within Aquifex pyrophilus DnaG, an archaeal form of primase. Priming and tailing are essential steps during rRNA maturation that allow correct folding of the molecule into its three-dimensional structure. Using electron microscopy, biochemical fractionation combined with transcriptomic studies on A. pyrophilus cells grown under protein synthesis-limiting conditions, we show that the N-terminal region specifically binds to mature 5S/23S rRNA molecules and protected them from degradation by RNases in vitro; moreover, it is required for efficient exosome association and 3' end formation through CCA addition. Our work reveals DnaG as a novel platform mediating the primosome assembly onto preprocessed ribonucleoprotein particles in archaea and establishes a role for it in forming correct folds of functional 25S rRNAs which facilitate their biogenesis.

title: Soluble Form of Canine Transferrin Receptor Inhibits Canine Parvovirus Infection In Vitro and In Vivo
abstract: This study focuses on the potential of using the soluble form of canine transferrin receptor (sTfR) as an inhibitor of canine parvovirus (CPV2) infection both in vitro and in vivo. Using an advanced production method, CPV2-specific sTfR was produced that demonstrated a higher binding capacity and neutralizing antibody activity when compared to its native form. Vaccination with purified recombinant sTfR provided significant protection from CPV2 infection for 84 days in dogs infected with viremia levels exceeding 1:1,200 dilutions; 90% neutralization at different subtypes of CPV2 could also be observed. In vitro studies revealed reduced infectivity by purine inhibition and toxicity assays, suggesting additional functional properties were established due to posttranslational modifications incorporated during protein expression. These results suggest that sTfR is a promising candidate molecule for use as an inhibitor or vaccine platform against CPV2 infection in infectious disease research or veterinary clinical settings.

title: Structural effects on the phosphorylation of 3-substituted 1-β-d-ribofuranosyl-1,2,4-triazoles by human adenosine kinase
abstract: This article explores the structural effects on adenosine kinase-catalyzed phosphorylation of 3-substituted 1-β-d-ribofuranosyl -1,2,4 triazole derivatives. Studies using a combination of in silico and experimental methods are used to evaluate the impact that different substituents have on positional selectivity during phosphorylation. The findings suggest that this type of small molecule can be tailored to optimally interact with enzyme active sites for efficient catalysis of chemical reactions relevant to drug discovery and development.

title: Aberrant remyelination of axons after heat injury in the dorsal funiculus of rat spinal cord
abstract: This article examines evidence of the effects of heat injury on remyelination in an animal model. Specifically, we investigate aberrant remyelination patterns observed following thermal excitation to rat dorsal funiculi at laboratory settings. The findings suggest that intense temperature fluctuations can cause a shift from normal remyelination activity and result in unexpected changes to axon myelin sheaths. We draw conclusions that support the relationship between altered environmental temperatures and neural fibre repair processes.

title: A new kind of beat
abstract: This study examines how introducing a new type of rhythmic structure affects the tempo, complexity and enjoyment of musical compositions. The 'new kind' beat uses four beats to introduce structural variety compared to prevailing six beats in popular music styles. Results reveal significant positive influences on tempo stability as well as music complexity and listener appreciation.

title: Editorial: Neurophotonics for you
abstract: This Editorial provides an overview of the emerging field of Neurophotonics, a combination of neuroscience and nanophotonic devices which promises to revolutionize medical treatments for neurological disorders. Our aim is to inform readers about the potential applications and benefits of this nascent discipline.

title: Enhancing the NICU language environment with a neonatal Cuddler program
abstract: This study investigated the effects of a neonatal Cuddler program on the language environment in a NICU setting. The results indicated that cuddlers are an effective intervention to enhance communication among staff, improve parent-infant engagement, and provide positive social support to infants and families during their hospital stay. It also revealed several benefits for cuddlers such as sense of purpose and psychological wellbeing. These findings suggest that implementation of this program can significantly contribute to improving outcomes for helpless preterm infants in a stressful medical setting.

title: T cell sensitization to proteolipid protein in myelin basic protein-induced relapsing experimental allergic encephalomyelitis
abstract: This paper investigates the role of T cells in sensitizing to proteolipid protein (PLP) expressed in myelin basic protein-induced relapsing experimental allergic encephalomyelitis (R-EAE). Using a murine model, we demonstrate that R-EAE is associated with an increased frequency of central nervous system-infiltrating T cells sensitized to PLP, providing evidence that these pathogenetic responses are key elements in the development and maintenance of disease activity. Furthermore, we also assess antigenic structure as part of our investigation into PLP sensitivity during R-EAE initiation and establishment.

title: Multiple lung abscesses due to acinetobacter infection: a case report
abstract: This case report presents the clinical course of a patient with multiple lung abscesses caused by Acinetobacter infection. A 50-year-old male presented with severe pneumonia, breathlessness and febrile episodes to our hospital. Investigations revealed widespread pulmonary infiltrates organized as multiple chest abscesses, due to multidrug resistant reactivation of a latent Acinetobacter baumannii infection. The patient was successfully treated with targeted antibiotics following fluid drainage of the chest abscesses using video assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS). This study highlights the importance in recognizing unusual manifestations of acinetobacter infection for prompt diagnosis and successful treatment.

title: Immunoproteomic analysis of Clostridium botulinum type B secretome for identification of immunogenic proteins against botulism
abstract: The growing number of cases of foodborne intoxication caused by Clostridium botulinum Type B presents a serious risk to human health. To identify immunogenic proteins responsible for immune protection against C. botulinum toxins, the current study has performed an immunoproteomic analysis using secretome samples from toxigenic strain ATCC 17393. A two-dimensional electrophoresis approach was employed followed by liquid chromatography mass spectrometry/mass spectrometry for protein identification and Western blotting for antibody recognition profiling. The results have identified several key antigens that induce significant antibody responses to all subtypes of C. botulinum, which may be candidate molecules contributing to effective vaccines design and development against this neurotoxic bacteria.

title: Was the fuss overblown?
abstract: The recent COVID-19 pandemic caused unprecedented levels of fear and turmoil all over the world. This study aims to address whether panic in populations, media hype, and governments' decisions were necessary or if they may have been exaggerated in some cases. We ran a statistical analysis of population responses and government policies from 4 countries previously severely stricken by the virus, and compared them with their neighboring countries for which similar data was available. Our results lead us to believe that ‘Was the Fuss Overblown?’ holds sway as an appropriate title for this research.

title: Chloroquine is effective against influenza A virus in vitro but not in vivo
abstract: This study examines the antiviral effectiveness of chloroquine against influenza A virus (IAV). Through in vitro and in vivo analysis, we establish that chloroquine exhibits a high degree of antiviral efficacy in the cell culture environment but is not able to achieve the same level of success when tested on animal hosts. The findings suggest that although optimistically promising, further research will be essential before chloroquine can be considered an effective antiviral drug for IAV-infected humans.

title: Evaluation of a Virucidal Quantitative Carrier Test for Surface Disinfectants
abstract: This study evaluates a novel, quantitative carrier test for surface disinfectants to determine their efficacy as virucides. The evaluation was conducted using both laboratory tests and 3D scanning technology to analyze the amount of virus removed from surfaces treated with different commercial products. The findings revealed that several common surface disinfectants eliminate up to 99.99% of viruses tested, including Human Coronavirus, Rotavirus and Norovirus types 1-3. Moreover, it was discovered that surfaces which were not pre-cleaned prior to treatment exhibited equivalent results when compared with those that were cleaned beforehand - demonstrating this simple but effective method of monitoring disinfectant effectiveness has the potential to be used on all surfaces in clinical settings without additional preparation time or supplies required for pre-treatment cleaning. This quantitative assay is highly specific, rapid and requires minimal sample preparation - providing a comprehensive solution for evaluation of advanced Virucidal activity in healthcare and domestic environments alike.

This quantitative assay is highly specific, rapid and requires minimal sample preparation - providing a comprehensive solution for evaluation of advanced Virucidal activity in healthcare and domestic environments alike.

evaluation of a virucidal quantitative carrier test for surface disinfectants 

this study evaluates a novel quantitative carrier test for surface disinfectants to determine their efficacy as virucides the evaluation was conducted using both laboratory tests and 3d scanning technology to analyze the amount of virus removed from surfaces treated with different commercial products the findings revealed that several common surface disinfectants eliminate up to 9999 of viruses tested including human coronavirus rotavirus and norovirus types 13 moreover it was discovered that surfaces which were not precleaned prior to treatment exhibited equivalent results when compared with those that were cleaned beforehand  demonstrating this simple but effective method of monitoring disinfectant effectiveness has the potential to be used on all surfaces in clinical settings without additional preparation time or supplies required for pretreatment cleaning this quantitative assay is highly specific rapid and requires minimal sample preparation  providing a comprehensive solution for evaluation of advanced virucidal activity in healthcare and domestic environments alike

title: Puromycin reactivity does not accurately localize translation at the subcellular level
abstract: In this study, we analyze the secondary structure of puromycin-labelled proteins to assess whether they accurately represent local translation events in the cellular context. Our results indicate that while binding and crosslinking of DNA to mRNA detectable by immunofluorescence are highly correlated with RNA translation, protein labeling is not reliable at such small scales. We reveal that coordination between post-transcriptional modifications including 5' and 3'end-processing do not allow for endstation localization on a subcellular level, leading to misinterpretations about gene expression regulation at these temporal resolutions. This suggests prudence when assessing mammalian cell activity solely off of indirect readouts from non-specific commodities such as puromycin.

title: Synthesis of Organotin Polyamine Ethers Containing Acyclovir and their Preliminary Anticancer and Antiviral Activity
abstract: This article presents a novel investigation into the synthesis and preliminary biological activity of organotin polyamine derivatives containing acyclovir. In an effort to address the dual challenges of cancer and viral infections, researchers were able to demonstrate how substituting oxygen atoms in previously employed metal-based radical initiators with tin gave rise to new precursors for synthesizing organotin polyamines that could carry the antiviral drug acyclovir. Subsequently, anticancer and antiviral properties were confirmed when these products underwent further testing using human cell lines in vitro.

title: Spanish Validation for Olfactory Function Testing Using the Sniffin’ Sticks Olfactory Test: Threshold, Discrimination, and Identification
abstract: This study aimed to provide Spanish validation for the Sniffin’ Sticks Olfactory Test (SOST), which is well-established and provides reliable results for measuring olfactory function. The data collected from 123 participants aged 18 years or older living in northern Spain analyzed three factors of the SOST: threshold, discrimination, and identification. Results from this study showed that SOST is a valid tool using Spanish instructions with good reliability coefficients for all three factors tested—therefore its use may be recommended as a psychometric instrument to assess olfactory impairment among Spanish populations seeking medical advice about their sense of smell. In addition, further research into individual assessment components could benefit our understanding of test validity in different patient samples and help to optimize the diagnostic use of this sensitive measure.

title: Transplantation of highly purified peripheral blood CD34(+) cells from HLA-mismatched parental donors in 14 children: evaluation of early monitoring of engraftment
abstract: This study evaluates the efficacy of transplantation utilizing highly purified peripheral blood CD34(+) cells from HLA-mismatched parental donors in fourteen children with leukemia and other conditions. To assess early monitoring of engraftment, we analyzed clinical outcomes pre- and post-transplantation including primary hematological recovery following myeloablative chemotherapy. We measured engraftment time, rate of neutrophil and platelet donor chimerism 3 months after transplantation, as well as acute graft versus host disease risk factors. The results indicate that it is feasible to use parental haploidentical CD34(+) cell transplants for pediatric patients receiving therapy for leukemic or immune deficiency diseases. Further, we have displayed an effective strategy to achieve rapid and durable full donor chimerism over 90% which should be indicative of functional immune reconstitution without development of acute graft versus host disease.?

title: Molluscum contagiosum and the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome: clinical and immunological details of two cases
abstract: This paper presents the clinical and immunological details of two cases that have resulted in the very rare association of Molluscum contagiosum (MC) with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). Through a review of these cases, we discuss how this combination is particularly more concerning than when MC occurs on its own. The aim is to explore recent findings about the relationships between HIV and MC to understand their implications for medical practice.

title: Dreams of flu data
abstract: This article focuses on the use of dream data to predict flu susceptibility among population groups. By exploring an innovative paradigm, we highlight a novel approach for tackling this public health issue. Dream data provide a valuable insight into individuals' vulnerability to influenza virus and can be used as a reliable predictive tool in epidemiological studies.

title: Antibody-mediated clearance of viruses from the mammalian central nervous system
abstract: This manuscript presents the novel finding that mammalian central nervous systems can be cleared of viruses with the assistance of antibodies. Combining traditional biological and biochemical characteristics with contemporary genomic approaches, we identified an antibody-driven mechanism by which clearance of a wide range of viruses from the CNS is achieved. The implications for treating viral infections affecting brain and spinal cord function are far reaching, potentially offering new therapies in an area lacking effective treatments.

title: Glucocorticoids in the treatment of acute respiratory distress syndrome
abstract: This article discusses a recent trend in the management of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), with glucocorticoids playing a prominent role. These medications, which include cortisone and prednisone, have recently been explored as supplemental therapy for ARDS patients to help reduce inflammation and improve mortality rates. The safety, efficacy and pharmacokinetics of glucocorticoid use in treating the disease will be assessed by analyzing several clinical trials that focus on their potential benefits. The results from these studies suggest promising prospects for further exploration into the role of glucocorticoids in treating ARDS.  ‘Glucocorticoids in the treatment of acute respiratory distress syndrome’

title: Interaction of a Densovirus with Glycans of the Peritrophic Matrix Mediates Oral Infection of the Lepidopteran Pest Spodoptera frugiperda
abstract: The effectiveness of insecticides to control lepidopteran pests, such as corn earworm Spodoptera frugiperda (S. Frugiperda), is being hampered by the development of resistance in field populations. Recent studies have implicated viruses in several ecological processes; however, an understanding of the interaction between densoviruses and peritrophic matrix proteins involved in oral infection remains largely unknown. Here we present a study investigating how densoviruses exploit the glycans within S. frugiperda’s peritrophic matrix for efficient oral transmission. Through quantitative PCR screening and gene editing, we demonstrate that this virus recognizes and exploits specific peritrophic glycan motifs which modulate their affinity for binding host receptors and ultimately increase viral infectivity via externalization. Our findings suggest possible regulatory strategies related to controlling S. frugiperda by blocking its recognition or attachment to certain glycans in order to constrain disease outbreaks, rather than relying on costly chemical pesticides alone. Interaction of a Densovirus with Glycans of the Peritrophic Matrix Mediates Oral Infection of the Lepidopteran Pest Spodoptera Frugiperda

title: Dendritic DNA Building Blocks for Amplified Detection Assays and Biomaterials
abstract: This paper presents the synthesis of dendritic DNA building blocks for use in amplified detection assays and biomaterials applications. By utilizing synthetic organic chemistry, the researchers were able to generate molecules with multi-domain scaffolds capable of hosting a large number of appended molecular sequences. The study provides new perspectives on how these DNA hybrids may be employed as novel drug delivery agents and nanostructures.

title: “In sickness and in health” – how neutrophil extracellular trap (NET) works in infections, selected diseases and pregnancy
abstract: The phenomenon of neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) is increasingly being recognized for its potential in supporting the innate immune system to fight against a wide range of pathogens. This study will explore the current knowledge on NETs, focusing particularly on their involvement during infectious processes, selected diseases and pregnancy. We also review recent advances to better understand this complex 'web-like' network and offer novel insights into how it may be best applied in each context. From these distinctive perspectives we examine its intricate role in maintaining “health” within infection and disease states, as epitomized by the popular phrase “in sickness and in health”.

title: The EU Elephant: Europe in the 2021 Dutch General Elections
abstract: This paper examines the Brexit-induced shift in voting dynamics in relation to the 2021 Dutch General Elections from a European perspective. The Elephant of EU power looms large, as voters decide which party will best represent their interests in a changed landscape.

title: Lactic acid production from lime-treated wheat straw by Bacillus coagulans: neutralization of acid by fed-batch addition of alkaline substrate
abstract: This study focuses on lactic acid production from lime-treated wheat straw by the novel alkaliphilic strain, Bacillus coagulans. The aim was to investigate the potential of fermentation with fed-batch addition of alkaline substrate for neutralizing acidic conditions caused by bacterial metabolism during lactic acid production. The results showed that B. coagulans used lime-treated wheat as a carbon source efficiently and produced high concentrations of lactic acid in an acidic environment with neutralization achieved through fed-batch addition of alkaline substrate into the fermenter. In conclusion, these findings contribute to development of efficient bioprocesses for sustainable use of alternative substrates for commercial applications such as feedstock for biofuel and textile industries or agricultural residues into various added value products like food additives and nutraceuticals.

title: Pandemic H1N1 2009 influenza virus with the H275Y oseltamivir resistance neuraminidase mutation shows a small compromise in enzyme activity and viral fitness
abstract: The emergence of drug-resistant strains of influenza is a concerning challenge for every pandemic control program. Here, we studied the impact of an oseltamivir resistance mutation in H1N1 2009 subtype neuraminidase (NA). Using reverse genetics, recombinant viruses containing the H275Y mutation were generated and characterized regarding NA activity and viral fitness. We found that the resistant virus loses about half its enzyme activity versus wild type strains but showed only marginal decreases in terms of infectivity, replication kinetics and growth yields. Thus, our findings confirm previous reports suggesting small compromise with regard to both enzymatic function and viral fitness when this drug-resistance marker appears in currently circulating seasonal or pandemic influenza A virus isolates.

title: A Survey of Recent Adenoviral Respiratory Pathogens in Hong Kong Reveals Emergent and Recombinant Human Adenovirus Type 4 (HAdV-E4) Circulating in Civilian Populations
abstract: This study provides a comprehensive overview of current human adenoviral respiratory pathogens in Hong Kong, revealing an emergent recombinant strain known as human adenovirus type 4 (HAdV-E4). Given the impact of respiratory viral infections on global health, it is important to understand the prevalence and dynamics of these pathogens. A population-based survey was employed using samples from clinically symptomatic patients attending hospital outpatient services for suspected respiratory illness over five years. The results revealed that HAdV-E4 was circulating among susceptible civilian populations in Hong Kong during the period under review. This study highlights the need for ongoing surveillance efforts and effective public health interventions to monitor and control emerging viruses at their respective source locations.

title: Paraplegia in a Domestic Ferret (Mustela Putorius Furo) Secondary to Metastatic Adrenocortical Carcinoma with Myxoid Differentiation
abstract: This study reports on the clinical manifestations, histopathology and treatment of a domestic ferret with metastatic adrenocortical carcinoma with myxoid differentiation presenting as paraplegia. Radiographs, computed tomography scans, serum biochemical analysis and histopathological evaluation were performed to morphologically characterize the mass located in thoracic spinal column. Histopathology highlighted malignant cells consistent with myxoid differentiation from ACC which was treatedwith palliative chemotherapy which provided some temporary relief of neurological symptoms.
